title: Jomala
text:
Jomala is a <a href="municipalities%20of%20Finland">municipality</a> of <a href="%C3%85land">Åland</a>, an autonomous territory of <a href="Finland">Finland</a>. In terms of population, it is the next largest after <a href="Mariehamn">Mariehamn</a>, the capital of <a href="%C3%85land">Åland</a>.
The municipality has a population of () and covers an area of of which is water. The <a href="population%20density">population density</a> is .
The municipality is unilingually <a href="Swedish%20language">Swedish</a>.
<a href="Mariehamn%20Airport">Mariehamn Airport</a> is located in Jomala. Three of Åland's four <a href="highway">highway</a>s cross the municipality of Jomala as they start from Mariehamn; <a href="Highway%201%20%28%C3%85land%29">highway 1</a> runs west to <a href="Ecker%C3%B6">Eckerö</a>, <a href="Highway%202%20%28%C3%85land%29">highway 2</a> northeast to <a href="Sund%2C%20%C3%85land">Sund</a> and <a href="Highway%203%20%28%C3%85land%29">highway 3</a> east to <a href="Lumparland">Lumparland</a>.
History.
"Jomala" is the name of a <a href="god">god</a> common to many <a href="Finnic%20peoples">Finnic peoples</a>. Jumala is Finnish for god and Jomala is one of the sites where the Christian church organized itself in Finland. Other versions of the name that have occurred are Jwmala in 1356, Jomalum in 1414, Jomala in 1486 and Jwmala in 1494. One of oldest churches in Finland stands here as testament to these times.
Jomala was inhabited around 2000 B.C with Jettböle being one of the most renowned prehistoric sites. Other ancient sites include Borgberget, where there was a Viking fortress, and Kasberget which was one of the many mountains where signal fires were lit when enemies were seen approaching.
Before the city of <a href="Mariehamn">Mariehamn</a> was established in 1861, the peninsula where the city is situated was a part of Jomala.
Sights.
<a href="Church%20of%20St.%20Olaf%2C%20Jomala">The church of Jomala</a> is dedicated to the <a href="patron%20saint">patron saint</a> of Åland, <a href="Olaf%20II%20of%20Norway">St. Olav</a>. It is the oldest surviving church in Finland and it is situated in the village of Prästgården. The oldest parts of the church date from the 13th century. The church tower is 52 meters tall and there is also a memorial for all the Ålanders who emigrated. Another memorial refers to sailors who lost their lives at sea. The "King of Åland" <a href="Julius%20Sundblom">Julius Sundblom</a> is buried here. A large medieval cemetery with graves from the <a href="Iron%20Age">Iron Age</a> can be visited behind the church.
The Lemström channel divides Jomala from its neighboring municipality, <a href="Lemland">Lemland</a>. It was widened by <a href="Russia">Russia</a>n <a href="Prisoner%20of%20war">POWs</a> in 1882.
The Kungsö <a href="artillery%20battery">battery</a> was one of the ten <a href="coastal%20artillery">coastal batteries</a> which the Russians built in Åland during the <a href="First%20World%20War">First World War</a> in 1916. The battery was situated 32 meters above <a href="sea%20level">sea level</a>, on the highest point of Dalsberg. Finnish, <a href="Sweden">Swedish</a> and <a href="Germany">German</a> troops invaded it in 1918. It was dismantled in 1919 by <a href="Finland">Finnish</a> civilian workers.
There are various well-preserved windmills in Jomala, e.g. on "Norrgård" farm in Björsby.
Culture.
Since Jomala belongs to the Swedish-speaking areas of Finland, <a href="Midsummer">Midsummer</a> is celebrated every year by hoisting up a <a href="maypole">maypole</a>. It was a tribute to the <a href="sun">sun</a> in the ancient times. Harvest festivities are held every September.
Geography.
Jomala is bordered by <a href="Lemland">Lemland</a> in the southwest, <a href="Mariehamn">Mariehamn</a> in the south, <a href="Hammarland">Hammarland</a> in the northwest, <a href="Finstr%C3%B6m">Finström</a> in the north and <a href="Sund%2C%20%C3%85land">Sund</a> in the northeast.
Villages.
These are Andersböle, Björsby, Buskböle, Dalkarby, Djurvik, Gottby, Gölby, Hammarudda, Hinderböle, Ingby, Jomalaby, Karrböle, Kila, Kungsöby, Möckelby, Möckelö, Norrsunda, Rasmansböle, Ringsböle, Sviby, Södersunda, Torp, Ulvsby, Vargsunda, Västansunda, Västerkalmar, Ytterby, Ytternäs, Ödanböle, <a href="%C3%96nningeby">Önningeby</a>, Österkalmar and Överby.
